channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: President Trump makes a statement about the National Guard shooting in D.C.
item.description: President Trump addresses the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, D.C. The shooting happened just a few blocks from the White House.
item.content:encoded: President Trump addresses the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, D.C. The shooting happened just a few blocks from the White House.
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: Remembering Susan Stamberg and the holiday recipe she shared with listeners
item.description: This Thanksgiving season, we remember Susan Stamberg, one of NPR's "founding mothers," who died this year. For decades, she shared a family recipe for cranberry relish with listeners.
item.content:encoded: This Thanksgiving season, we remember Susan Stamberg, one of NPR's "founding mothers," who died this year. For decades, she shared a family recipe for cranberry relish with listeners.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: A northern lights love poem
item.description: When the northern lights dramatically lit up skies across the country earlier this month, poet Silas House was among those of us dazzled from below.
item.content:encoded: When the northern lights dramatically lit up skies across the country earlier this month, poet Silas House was among those of us dazzled from below.
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: Former U.S. diplomat Kurt Volker on how Trump is handling Ukraine negotiations
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with former U.S. Special Representative for Ukraine Kurt Volker, about the latest in the Trump administration's unconventional approach to negotiating a peace deal.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with former U.S. Special Representative for Ukraine Kurt Volker, about the latest in the Trump administration's unconventional approach to negotiating a peace deal.
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: How is it going for travelers at busy airports this holiday week?
item.description: Millions of Americans are flying to visit family and friends this holiday season. It's a big test of the U.S. aviation system after weeks of disruptions caused by the government shutdown.
item.content:encoded: Millions of Americans are flying to visit family and friends this holiday season. It's a big test of the U.S. aviation system after weeks of disruptions caused by the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Was the first 'Thanksgiving' feast actually along the Rio Grande?
item.description: Thanksgiving is steeped in stories of pilgrims and native people enjoying a harvest feast in Plymouth. But historians say the first "Thanksgiving" was 23 years earlier, in 1598 along the Rio Grande.
item.content:encoded: Thanksgiving is steeped in stories of pilgrims and native people enjoying a harvest feast in Plymouth. But historians say the first "Thanksgiving" was 23 years earlier, in 1598 along the Rio Grande.
item.dc:creator: Angela Kocherga

item.title: A 40-year-old Scout tradition of food donation got its start in St. Louis
item.description: During the holiday season, young Scouts across the country work to collect food items for local pantries. It's an annual event, called Scouting for Food, that's more than 40 years old.
item.content:encoded: During the holiday season, young Scouts across the country work to collect food items for local pantries. It's an annual event, called Scouting for Food, that's more than 40 years old.
item.dc:creator: Lacretia Wimbley

item.title: Why kids are leading the charge back to movie theatres
item.description: PG-rated movies are leading the drive back to theaters following COVID, and the film industry has kids to thank!
item.content:encoded: PG-rated movies are leading the drive back to theaters following COVID, and the film industry has kids to thank!
item.dc:creator: Kai McNamee

item.title: Tribal colleges in the U.S. are under threat
item.description: At tribal colleges and universities, students can get degrees while steeped in Indigenous traditions and learning techniques. Under the Trump administration, funding for them has been precarious.
item.content:encoded: At tribal colleges and universities, students can get degrees while steeped in Indigenous traditions and learning techniques. Under the Trump administration, funding for them has been precarious.
item.dc:creator: Dalia Mortada

item.title: Historic murals inside a D.C. federal building may face an uncertain future
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks to art historian Mary Okin about the significance and uncertain future of the historic murals painted inside the Wilbur J. Cohen Federal Building in Washington, D.C.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks to art historian Mary Okin about the significance and uncertain future of the historic murals painted inside the Wilbur J. Cohen Federal Building in Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug
